pros: Working for Auburn has its advantages. The accrual of Paid Time Off and Sick-Leave is fair ONLY if you're fortunate enough to have a supervisor who supports the idea of work/life balance. The students are overall great and wonderful to work with. The campus is beautiful and Auburn is a charming small town. Integrating with a variety of departments is fun!
cons: To work for Auburn and enjoy it, some may say you will need to "drink the kool-aid" and for the most-part, that is true. The pay is HORRIBLE! Elitism is very prevalent! HR thinks everyone must work harder, but we need to be paid better! The job family idea does not work. The only opportunity for a raise is to be "promoted" and it's a 5% max. They took away our tiny, yearly "bonus". Yes, the VP received 200,000.00 checks over COVID. Speak up and you most likely will be shunned. Tons and tons of employees feel the same way but we keep it to ourselves. We lost our nice sports ticket discount because our old CFO thought it was too much of a benefit. Chances for growth are slim to none. Women aren't typically put in positions of power. It's a good ole boy system, they know it, they do not admit it and you'll be slapped for saying it out loud.

review_title: Facilities Management - I can no longer recommend anyone work here.
pros: 1) Autonomy. 2) Employer matching retirements. 3)Time off. 4) My supervisor.
cons: 1) Upper management are arrogant and hide in the chain of command. 2) Goal posts are constantly shifted regarding pay and pay ranges. 3) Pay is not competitive, but mediocre and determined by narrow, local industry average. FMHR still wonder why they cannot attract the candidates they seek. They subscribe to the trope that no one wants to work. 4) Techs forced to wear outdated brown shirts with billboard patches. 5) Any yearly pay raise (~5%) will be negated by insurance premium increase (~17%). 6) HR assumes everyone needs to improve. review_title: Not a bad place to work overall.
job_title: Research Assistant II in Auburn, AL
pros:
Decent benefits package. Free classes after working full-time for a year. Depending on the individual college and department, you may find a great community. My department felt like a family. 
I learned a lot while I was there. I gained many new skills and earned an advanced degree. I felt like my work mattered.
cons:
Pay was underwhelming; my starting wage was almost insulting, but I was overqualified and I took it because desperate after a year of unemployment. I got along well with everyone until one of our new hires was unhappy with life and started playing political games. By the time she left, most people in the department thought I was a lazy slacker. I came to dread going to work, even though I enjoyed the work itself. 

Some departments are toxic. My department was mostly great, but another department in my college was so political I could almost feel the tension when I walked by.

Official job titles and descriptions are not terribly helpful, but that probably depends on your supervisor; mine had me doing a huge range of tasks, each of which would otherwise have required someone who would charge double my pay. 

As with most places, HR exists to protect the employer, not the employee. In my experience, they approach accommodation requests with extreme skepticism, and in my case, thinly veiled hostility.

review_title: Hope and Pray you don't get a bad supervisor or division superior
pros: Organizationally, they're rethinking and redoing some things. There are some truly great people across the different divisions, and the right leadership makes all the difference. If your division or department is important to the university at the time (it changes every few years) you'll be well-supported and your work will be rewarded. Academics, fundraising, athletics, and recreation are the best examples of this. If you're fortunate enough to work with students, you'll be able to make a positive difference in their lives.
cons: The "family" tagline is just marketing, so don't expect it to be reality. Black employees will very quickly see that there are different rules for us than the white employees who will get treated better over the long haul. Public sector, so pay is mediocre at best. Every year the insurance goes up, the benefits become less valuable. They are far too traditional and restricted in their thinking, so things that make common sense for your dept, your position, or your work will be ignored. They will side with management 99/100 times, so just hope you get one that's reasonable and values your mental health and wellbeing. Some do, some don't. If they don't, don't assume it will get better. Find yourself something better in the private sector and try again when you find something with a better supervisor or dept head. If you're qualified, you're always going to be able to get into the running for a job you want because they have a really hard time getting people to apply for jobs with this pay in this area. So just wait it out.

review_title: "You have to accept the bad with the good"
pros: Department encourages and pays for trainees to attend professional conferences and workshops for continuing education and networking. The environment is for the most part supportive.  The support staff is hardworking and absolutely wonderful to work with. The faculty did their best to encourage trainees to network for job and training opportunities. Low cost of living in the area.
cons: Trainees are in a weird, undefined space between employee and student. There is no guideline to juggling the residency responsibilities and taking graduate courses (which are required to maintain your stipend/salary). The offered subsidized student health insurance is mediocre. There is no coverage for medical specialists, dental, and eye insurance. There are no retirement or disability benefits. There aren't enough faculty in the department, many are spread thin which causes some to feel overworked and under appreciated. There isn't equal effort given among the faculty to training residents, which causes some to develop compassion fatigue. Some of the faculty have an elitist disposition which emits a pretentious vibe and causes discord among the other faculty members.

pros: Relaxed ;  Great work-life balance.  Benefits.
cons:
Still living by the "good old boy" world.  
Extremely slow paced.  By the time implementation of a new product is approved (~2-4 months), newer/better technology exists and the process starts over.  
Too many products doing the same thing across various departments (wasted money);  when upgrades are performed - systems break.
While internal customers are extremely important, their "input" should not interferes with the overall good of the university and a productive business structure.

review_title: Great Campus Job for Dedicated Students
job_title: Student Athlete Tutor in Auburn, AL
pros:
- Flexible work hours. As a tutor, you are free to schedule your weekly appointments whenever it is convenient for you and your student athlete.
- Good pay. Most tutors average $9-$10 per hour, depending on experience. This is well above the minimum wage students can expect to get at other service industry jobs ( waitress, cashier, etc.) off campus. 
- Dependable. Your schedule does not change from week to week. However, you do have the ability to change if something comes up.
cons: -Schedule Changes. You are working with student athletes. They often have to attend tournaments or away games. It is on you to reschedule your session, or lose that hour for the week. The students are very good about working with you on that; they want to have their tutoring session each week too.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Auburn, AL
pros: Some advisors are good. It is a research school, so there is a lot of RA and TA positions available, which cover your tuition, plus a small stipend. Warm weather most of the year.
cons: Technology at Auburn needs updating. The school is overly obsessed with football. The stipend for a TA or RA is relatively very low compared to other schools. Some advisors are awful. The biggest con is that AU is in the southern region of the U.S. If you are like me, then you want to have your career after school anywhere except in the south. Almost all the employers you network with while at Auburn want you to work for them locally, which makes finding a job after college just a little bit harder... like we need finding jobs to be any harder than it already is.

pros: You get up to 5 hours of free tuition for the coursework and dependents get 50% off tuition rates.
cons: Pay is the lowest in the region, having advanced degrees doesn't count for squat, climbing the ladder and getting positions is all in who you know and a popularity contest.  Basically thing of working here as being in High School on steroids. Too many politics and for a school so old and big they are operating as if they are in the stone age.  Also they are constantly changing policies which ultimately hurts the students.

pros: Great benefits, diverse people, many areas to involve yourself, it is a Monday-Friday 8-5 job, two weeks off at Christmas, and a sense of community of the Auburn Family
cons: President Leath wants to take away the two weeks at Christmas. Many policies, workflows, and decisions are based on either antiquated processes or what looks good on paper. There is often very little follow-up or direction past initial meetings. The meetings don't stop, just the information and clarity do.

pros: Auburn was a great place to work. People are genuinely friendly and helpful. How seriously rules and regulations are followed will vary widely depending upon the office you work in. Most of the benefits are pretty good.
cons: There is not much room to move up and HR makes lateral moves almost impossible because they're so stingy with the salaries. Auburn pays for 5 credit hours of courses after you've been employed for one year, forcing you to either take 1 class (3 hours) and take forever to get a degree or take two classes (6 hours) and pay out of pocket for 1 hour each semester to finish in a reasonable amount of time.

pros: Payday and time off at Christmas
cons: Racism, sexual harassment, discrimination, hostile work environment, illiterate directors/bosses. You can work your rear off, but the black person will get the raise and promotion. Save your energy. Good ole boy network is alive and well here! Some of the most ignorant, just plain stupid people that I have ever encountered. And the scary part, most are in positions of power! Auburn needs a really good house cleaning, if you know what I mean. If you don't have a moral compass, you'll fit right in. Horrible place to work!  All the positive reviews are written by the dishonest stuffed shirts and frauds that have the most to lose.

job_title: Student Worker: Library in Auburn, AL
pros: The University has many opportunities for students to work on campus, which makes things very convenient when you can go to class and go to work in one commute. Working at the library is extra convenient when you can work on your homework during downtime. The job is incredibly easy and doesn't require much training, as long as you know Dewey Decimal System. The computer system is very easy to learn and doesn't have many errors.
cons: If you work alongside salaried staff, you run the chance of being stepped on or seen as disposable. Getting a raise as a student is incredibly difficult. But a worthwhile effort.

review_title: Great for Graduate Students, but choose professor wisely
pros: If you get a good professor, they will make sure you have both time outside of your research for studying for classes as well as time for your personal life. Graduate classes are also understanding that if you are doing research, your focus will be split between the research and class. The pay and the free tuition I received for my research wasn't too bad either.
cons: If you do your research under some professors, they don't care as much about your life outside of the research, and you will be working over 50-60 hours a week on top of your classes.

job_title: Physics Instructor in Auburn Univ, AL
pros:
I was a part time instructor for the physics department for 5 semesters.
Even as a part time instructor, I was given lots of flexibility in the content and the conduction of classes. 
The workload was minimal at 15-20 hours a week. This would be higher for instructors with less experience or that require more preparation, or don't teach the same class repeatedly. 
Very little supervision / over-management by supervisors; they trust their employees.
cons:
Salary is non negotiated at a fixed $10,000 per course before taxes.
9 month contracts, renewed yearly.
No / minimal support for summer semester.
Naturally, no benefits.
No career opportunities.

review_title: Wonderful community.  An example of the South at its best.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Auburn, AL
pros: I will miss my time here at Auburn after I graduate.  The culture here is very friendly and laid-back, and there are plenty of opportunities to connect with employers in the Southeast region.  Also, since Auburn is a small town, it's very easy to live close to school, shopping, restaurants, and other places if interest -- minimizing driving time.
cons: Auburn becomes a ghost town in the summer, and especially during school breaks.  There's not much to do during this time, unless you want to drive to Atlanta.  Also, as a research assistant, you're not going to make very much salarywise, but Auburn will waive your tuition as part of your compensation.

review_title: A university with much room remaining in which to grow and modernize
pros: Excellent and ambitious colleagues among faculty and new visions provided by a few recent administrative hires
cons: Overly dependent on state fiscal support, still burdened with legacy administration, practices, policies and organization, faculty remain on continuing path to becoming second-class citizens within context of administrative bloat and ineffectiveness, workloads far above regional average of peer institutions with correspondingly poor compensation and benefits across the majority of the workforce

review_title: You really have to stay on track or you may prolong your time in grad school.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Auburn, AL
pros:
-Plenty of freedom to take classes outside physics department.
-Downtown Auburn and Opelika offer just enough to do when you aren't working.
-There are plenty of opportunities to use and learn some of the more reputable software for engineering and scientific disciplines. 
-Most groups make the means for their students to do collaborative work at other universities. 
-My particular advisor consistenly goes above and beyond his duties and expectations so I have had  a very positive experience.
cons:
-The town is pretty small
-There are graduate doctoral exams that are notoriously difficult. Usually about 20% of students each year fail and have to leave the program.

pros: I worked for the vet school and overall I loved the job. The pay was decent for office work and it was easy. 75% of the staff were great to work with. There is a chance of promotion.
cons: A lot of doctors were VERY rude and acted like they were better than anyone under them, especially office staff. Very cliquey environment. AWFUL management when I was there. One girl was sexually harassed and the management asked her if she was just being too sensitive... and went back and told the doctor that she complained about everything without discliplining him and made things worse.

review_title: AU Fund is a great place to work for a student!
pros: Family atmosphere and many opportunities to learn. The supervisors are very caring and they know how it is to be a student worker. The people that you work with are friendly and come from a variety of backgrounds around campus.
cons: The call center can be sort of monotonous, but you are doing a great service for the university and students that currently attend. Hours are easily changed to meet last minute study needs, but they have to be made up before the end of the semester.

review_title: The Loveliest Village on the Plains
pros: Auburn is uniquely located and honors traditions. The Samuel Ginn College of Engineering is on the up and up. But if you are moving to the university by 2015 and afterward, be aware that major financial model changes will be in effect.
cons: Politics dominate the campus and community. There are many "old money" types living in the area. That being said, it is still a great place to live and work because the area is well funded by the taxes

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Auburn University, AL
pros: Working for Auburn was one of the best experiences I have ever had. I hope to go back someday but until then I will give it a great review. I worked for Auburn in the Office of Information Technology for a little over 3 years in their Helpdesk department. As a student it offered me a way to work part time or full time and go to school full time. I had three bosses and they were all wonderful to work with and the support offered while learning a new position was exemplary. I could not recommend working for Auburn University more!
cons: There are only a few available non student positions.

review_title: Good people, awful pay and benefits
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Auburn, AL
pros: Access to cutting edge technology for research. Professors are knowledgeable and approachable. Many well respected professors in their fields.
cons: Pay after insurance is taken out and fees are paid back each semester is near poverty line (in my department anyways). And you're not allowed to take a second job. Other graduate students make significantly more in other departments. The student health insurance is the worst plan I've ever seen. Be prepared to call the insurance company multiple times for each visit to the doctor to make sure you're covered.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Auburn, AL
pros: There is always immense pride associated with working at Auburn University, and you can get access to locked buildings for bathroom breaks during football tailgating
cons: As a graduate teaching assistant, you don't really get any benefits and work way more hours than the number you are paid for. You may be asked to cover your main professor's class with very little notice.

review_title: Environment and attitude is far from the positive image AU likes to portray in media.
pros: Is in a convenient location within a small community
cons: Discriminatory practices, gossip, and back-biting common within the "AU Family".No job training,no job description, a very closed environment to anyone considered an outsider. A place where your supervisor can't be bothered to even learn your name. Same supervisor degrades other employees to outside contractors, in presence of anyone listening.Very disillusioning to a life-long fan, supporter, former student, and AU parent.

review_title: Good place to Work as a PhD researcher
job_title: Current Phd Student in Auburn, AL
pros: Amazing Facilities. Library-Lab-Support Staff for Research-Teaching Faculty. The professors at the civil engineering department are very good. Coursework is good.
cons: The university setting is in an isolated location, getting jobs are hard, sometimes the faculty and support staff are laid back. If you enjoy a fast paced research experience, this is not the place to be.

review_title: Great Employeer, even for part-time workers
job_title: Tutor and Monitor in Auburn, AL
pros: I work as a tutor and front desk monitor for the SADC on campus. The staff are all very friendly, and the work is great. I enjoy tutoring, and the tutor coordinator is wonderful at her job.
cons: The hours can be a bit sporadic, and you can sometimes be there for several hours but only earn a fraction of the pay because you only get paid for the time spent with students, even if the student decides they only want to stay for 15min out of the 60min appt.

pros: Helping Auburn Alumni receive valuable information about the school and the progress Auburn is making in all departments.
cons: I did not really find any cons with this job, i loved doing the job but unfortunately i had to leave for higher pay. I do not do that but being paid minimum wage and only getting 20 hours a week was not paying the bills. i am a determined worker and i do not quit jobs, this however was unfortunate.

pros: free housing, stipend, discounted parking and more flexible meal plan
cons: Very limited to how often you can leave Auburn, on weekends you're onsite you have to be back in the building by 10 pm. On weekends you have to do 2 am rounds. RA training is 2 weeks out of your summer and isn't very effective

job_title: Career Counselor in Auburn University, AL
pros: Kind and supportive colleagues.  An at times, engaged student body that is passionate about their respective causes.  Opportunities for professional development and training.
cons: Limited ability to have career progression.  Does not reward years of service in any viable way. Out of touch higher administration with little idea of how actual program administrators and student service providers operate.

pros: The RFID Lab at Auburn University is the premier research facility for RFID advancement and technology. You're able to learn the ins and outs of this rapidly growing field and all of the implications that this technology has to offer.
cons: You need to be comfortable with speaking in front of large groups of people. This includes giving presentations to interested companies and members of the board, to giving tours on a daily basis in the Lab.

review_title: Best place to work in Auburn
pros: Auburn University has fantastic benefits and a great overall atmosphere. They are one of the few places that make it seem like they actually care about their staff. You will be welcomed as part of the Auburn family and will enjoy working with everyone.
cons: A lot of people do not plan on leaving auburn until they retire, this can make it very hard for positions to open and to advance through your field. Sometimes communication between different departments can be poor. It seems that every department has a different way of handling the same thing.

job_title: Mathematics Tutor/Content Developer in Auburn, AL
pros:
It's a great place to think for yourself- autonomy and creativity are highly valued.
Student-Athlete Support Services (SASS), where I currently work, is outstanding with listening to concerns and implementing solutions from employee feedback.
cons:
Preparation is sometimes required outside of tutoring sessions. 
Additionally, available content resources are lacking in some subject areas, so having creativity in teaching methods is a must.

pros: You can enjoy your life here, without much stress. Every one here is very nice and would like to offer help. It's very quiet place, you can focus yourself on your research.
cons: You cannot push through yourself. The life pace is so low. If you select someone never cares about you, you need to said to yourself: what is your goal, what do you want. Rather than spend rest of your life here.

review_title: Campus Recreation- Great starting part time job
job_title: Campus Recreation Operations Supervisor in Auburn, AL
pros: Easy schedule to work with, great manager and very relaxed atmosphere.  Was a very nice first job as it allowed me to mess up multiple times and not get in a lot of trouble.  Great chance to get a supervisor promotion and earn leadership experience as well.
cons: No phone use policy and communication can be rough some times.  Scheduler works 2 weeks ahead of time so any unknown tests or short notice assignments can get in the way sometimes.  Be prepared to clean up a lot of bodily fluids.

pros: Retirement system is the best in the nation.
cons: Administration is not supportive and does not provide the necessary tools to meet the research requirements, I.e. old equipment, prior to hire faculty get all of the goo, working equipment leaving new faculty with virtually old, non-working equipment, poor teamwork among faculty, much lower pay than comparable universities, health insurance is extremely high, administration does not support non-tenured faculty, tenured faculty does not support non-tenured faculty, very political at Auburn; would not recommend working at this institution

pros: The staff, whether professional or student, always had a pleasant and happy demeanor. The purpose of the Recreation and Wellness Center is to produce productivity amongst its employees and members of the facility. And it is evident the Recreation and Wellness Center attends to those needs.
cons: The Recreation and Wellness Center has odd hours during the holidays, but it should be understandable based on its numbers throughout those events. Also, the top management is not very personable.

job_title: Temporary Services Employee in Roswell, GA
pros:
I loved the sense of community that the University has, you can walk from one side of campus to the other and probably see many different people you know especially if you went to school at AU.
Temporary Services is a great opportunity for someone who hasn't worked for a University to get experience doing so. 
Walk-able Campus not only inside the campus but also to downtown for lunch and events.
cons:
Parking is a huge issue for everyone: students, faculty and staff, and temporary employees.
Lack of potential growth for temp employees to full time employment on campus.

review_title: Graduate student / research assistant in a science field.
pros: Nice campus, and Auburn is a nice town to live in. Relaxed and generally friendly atmosphere. Sufficent resources to excel in your studies or research if you are properly motivated.
cons: While quite a lot of research is conducted at Auburn, you can get the feeling that you are working from the outside. It is far away from cities having much in the way of stem jobs, for example. The environment may not be compatible with you if you are completely on the work side of the life/work balance.

job_title: Building Specialist in Auburn University, AL
pros: Auburn University Athletics Department was a great atmosphere to work in. Always something different. Work  was never boring
cons: Not sure exactly what you have to do to get hired full time with AU because for a solid year I worked my self to death for them in a temp job to only get released of my assignment abruptly.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Auburn, AL
pros: Beautiful campus and college town atmosphere. Very friendly atmosphere. Good facilities and outstanding researchers in my field (electronics reliability, lead-free solders).
cons: If you like the big-city life, Auburn is not for you. University bureaucracy moves slightly faster than most ice sheets.

job_title: Writing Center Consultant in Auburn, AL
pros: Great leadership, great coworkers, commitment to growing and really helping the student body, very flexible hours, great opportunity to develop your own career goals
cons: Not many hours, parking is always a nightmare, you must be willing and able to work well on your own with little to no micromanagement or supervision (which is not necessarily a con at all)

pros: The kids that you work with within the university are the salt of the Earth. Administration within the particular colleges are caring and precise.
cons: Football shuts the city down. If you are not an avid sports fan, you might want to look elsewhere during the fall semesters.

review_title: Good place to work. Nice, quiet town. If you like slow places, you'll love it.
job_title: Supv, Audio Visual in Auburn University, AL
pros: Health insurance and retirement benefits are amazing. Work load will likely not be too much to handle.
cons: Pay grade and structure aren't likely to be flexible. If you contribute more than your job description specifies, don't expect to get compensated for it.

Two weeks paid time off at Christmas and a generous vacation leave and sick leave program. I have always gotten at least a 2-3% annual raise in the 7 years I have been at Auburn.
cons: Parking sucks immensely and doesn't appear to be getting better.

review_title: A Great Place to Work to Get Gaslit and Dismissed in Violation of FMLA
pros:
1.  Decent salary and insurance.
2.  Allowed me to take courses towards an advanced degree.
3.  All Department Chairs until the last one were very supportive and proactive.
cons:
1.  It is a gossipy, backbiting, petty work environment.  Employees spy on each other.
2.  I was gaslit because some of the professors did not like me and, as a result, was dismissed from my position three years before retirement, which was in bad faith.
3.  My dismissal occurred on the fifth day after a meeting with the Chair when, by federal law, I had 15 days to submit FMLA paperwork.

review_title: If you are an international (non American) person, run away from this place
pros: This place it good if you are a middle aged, football loving, conservative (and preferably Caucasian)  American. If you do not fit into one of these categories, then read on.
cons:
I list below some of the problems with this place.  I have tried to keep them as dispassionate as possible -

1)  Location - As such, location is a MAJOR disadvantage.  Not only are you in rural Alabama, the closest decent airport (Atlanta) is 2 hours away, and in a different time zone.  What this means is that you have to leave home at 5:30 for a 9:30 flight.  Not fun!
  
2) Diversity - If you are an international person (either faculty or student), the "Office of International Affairs" will do nothing to help you.  In fact, they will do everything they can to make your life hard.  I know, because I am an international faculty member, and just went through hell to get my green card.  In fact, I had actually to threaten to resign to get the job done.  So be prepared.  If you are an American of color, then it is a little better than being a foreigner, but still, this isn't the best place you can be at.

3)  University Life - Academically, the place is fine, but other departments like Payroll and accounting are a pain to deal with.  I think they have been trained to treat college money as their own money, which is why they make it so hard to get money released to you.  You need every shred of documentation, and it can get very time consuming.  My biggest problem is that they expect you to buy your travel tickets / conference registration, etc. on your own credit card, then send your credit card statement to them, and after that they will reimburse.  Personally, I hate sharing my credit card statement with anyone.

4)  Opportunities for the Spouse - If your spouse wants to pursue a full time career, then forget about it.  There are few opportunities at the University itself, and even those are usually filled by temporary employment services (and the pay for those is rock bottom).  Other than the university, there are not too many other opportunities here yet (though that is improving slowly).  The closest opportunities are in Columbus (40 miles away) or Montgomery (50 miles away).  

5)  Entertainment and other activities - Are you kidding me?  There is absolutely NOTHING to do in this place.  Friday nights, the most exciting thing you can do is to go shopping at Tiger Town (which, BTW isn't  anything to write home about)!  There are a decent number of restaurants around town though, especially for a town this size.  

6)  Salary  and cost of living - Auburn is known for being a below average paymaster as far as universities go.  And the fact that this place has a state income tax, city tax, AND a 9% sales tax to top it off, does not make it the easiest place to live in.  Also note that there are relatively few sub 220 thousand $ homes around this place.  Most decent homes are 245,000 and up.

To sum up, while there are several worse places you could potentially be at, there are many better places too.  If you are not a student, and can work somewhere else, you are probably better off doing it.
